_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Final Mile Cold Storage has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Final Mile Cold Storage, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Final Mile Cold Storage has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                 | Process Chemical                | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Process 1 (East)               Anhydrous Ammonia                 26,000

Process 2 (West)               Anhydrous Ammonia                 28,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.

1. Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have:

2. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

3. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices



Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Descriptions



1.2.1 Facility Overview



Final Mile Cold Storage operates a commercial cold storage for bread and various other goods in Fresno, CA. The facility has two ammonia refrigeration systems that provide refrigeration capacity to the following:

P1 - East System

(14) Cold Storage Rooms

(1) Tray Pack Room



P2 - West System

(1) Loading Dock

(2) Freezers

(1) Receiving Dock

(1) Blast Cell Corridor

(12) Blast Cells

(1) Deslatting Room



1.2.2 Facility Location



Final Mile Cold Storage is located at 2950 East California Avenue, Fresno, CA 93721. The latitude and longitude of the largest high pressure receiver is 36.720673, -119.774579. The facility is located approximately 1/2 mile east of state highway 41 in an industrial area surrounded primarily by various businesses.

According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is partly located in "an area of minimal flood hazard" and partly located in a "special flood hazard area". The elevation of the machinery rooms were designed with the flood hazards in mind.



Final Mile Cold Storage is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that there are no faults in close proximity to the site. The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Final Mile Cold Storage has a 1-2% chance of experiencing "potentially minor-damage" due to ground shaking in 2018.

reas are equipped with air-cooling evaporators which are supplied from a recirculator as required for pumped overfeed operation.

Most control valve groups are located on the roof to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within or directly above the machinery room. A partial list of system components includes:

Process Chemistry



High Pressure Receivers

The purpose of the high pressure receivers is to provide a safe location to add and store high pressure liquid ammonia in the refrigeration systems. The high pressure receivers receive high pressure liquid from the condensers and thermosyphon vessel and supply high pressure liquid to each zone of refrigeration and liquid recirculator. The high pressure receivers are also used to provide storage for ammonia not being used in the processes at any given moment. The high pressure receivers are equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system. Under normal conditions, the high pressure receivers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Controlled Pressure Receiver

The purpose of the controlled pressure receiver (CPR) is to provide a safe location to add and store liquid ammonia at a constant pressure in the east refrigeration system. The controlled pressure receiver receives liquid from high pressure receiver that is supplied by the condensers. The CPR is maintained at an intermediate pressure that is less than the condensing pressure, but greater than the suction pressure. From the CPR, liquid is supplied to various zones of refrigeration. The CPR is also used to provide storage for ammonia not being used in the process at any given moment. The CPR is equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow o

f ammonia throughout the system. Under normal conditions, the CPR contains intermediate pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Intercooler

The purpose of the intercooler is to desuperheat and condense the booster discharge gas and to supply low pressure liquid to the liquid recirculator. The intercooler also receives and subcools liquid from the high pressure receivers in order to supply lower pressure liquid to the liquid recirculator. Ammonia vapor is piped from the top of the intercooler into the suction inlet of each high stage compressor. The intercooler is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the intercooler contains low pressure liquid and vapor.



High Temperature Recirculators

The purpose of the high temperature recirculators is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid that can be used in high temperature evaporators throughout the facility. The high temperature recirculators receive liquid from the high pressure receivers and supply, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the ammonia pumps mounted underneath the vessels. Liquid and vapor returned from the evaporators is separated inside the recirculators to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each high stage compressor. The high temperature recirculators are equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the high temperature recirculators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Low Temperature Recirculators

The purpose of the low temperature recirculators is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid that can be used in low temperature evaporators throughout the facility. The low temperature recirculators receive liquid from the high temperature recircula

tor and supply, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the ammonia pumps mounted underneath the vessels. Liquid and vapor returned from the evaporators is separated inside the recirculators to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each low stage compressor. The low temperature recirculators are equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the low temperature recirculators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Oil Pots/Oil Still

The purpose of the oil pots and oil still is to provide a safe location to drain oil from the refrigeration system. The oil pots receive liquid ammonia and oil from the recirculators and vent ammonia vapor back to the recirculators. The oil still receives liquid ammonia and oil from the recirculator and intercooler. The oil pots and oil still are equipped with spring-return oil drain valves which are used to drain oil from the systems as needed. Under normal conditions, the oil pots and oil still contain low pressure liquid ammonia, low pressure vapor ammonia, and refrigerant oil.



Air-Cooling Evaporators (Pumped Overfeed)

The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the recirculators. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it returns to the supplying vessel. Under normal conditions, the air-cooling evaporato

rs contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Air-Cooling Evaporators (Direct Expansion)

The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the controlled pressure receiver or intercooler. Each evaporator is equipped with an expansion valve which reduces the pressure and temperature of the liquid as it enters the evaporator. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it exits the evaporator and is returned to the suction accumulator. 



Suction Accumulator

The purpose of the suction accumulator is to prevent liquid from entering the compressors. The suction accumulator receives vapor from the Room 1 evaporators and separates any residual liquid from the vapor to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each compressor. Liquid in the suction accumulator drains by gravity into the liquid transfer vessel. The suction accumulator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the suction accumulator contains low pressure vapor ammonia.



Liquid Transfer Unit

The purpose of the liquid transfer unit is to transfer liquid from the low side of the refrigeration system back to the high pressure receivers. The liquid transfer unit receives liquid from the suction accumulator. Once the liquid level in the liquid transfer unit reaches the float switch, the

three way solenoid valve is energized for a period of time causing the liquid transfer unit to become subject to high pressure and activating the transfer pumps which move the liquid to the high pressure receivers. Under normal conditions the liquid transfer unit and transfer pumps can contain either high or low pressure liquid and vapor.



Compressors

The purpose of the compressors is to raise the temperature and pressure of the low pressure gas in order to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporators to the atmosphere. The compressors receive low pressure vapor from the recirculators (west system), suction accumulator, or intercooler (east system), and discharge high pressure vapor to the evaporative condensers. The compressors are equipped with high discharge pressure cutouts to shut the equipment off if the pressure exceeds the setpoint. Under normal conditions, the compressors contain both high and low pressure vapor ammonia.



Evaporative Condensers

The purpose of the evaporative condensers is to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporators to the atmosphere. The evaporative condensers receive high pressure, superheated vapor from the compressors and supply high pressure liquid to the high pressure receivers/thermosyphon vessel. The condensers use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receivers/thermosyphon vessel. Under normal conditions, the evaporative condensers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Underfloor Warming Heat Exchanger

The purpose of the underfloor warming heat exchanger is to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporators to the water being pumped through the heat exchanger. The underfloor warming heat exchanger receives high pressure vapor from the compressors, then supplies high pressure liquid to the high pressure receiver. U

nder normal conditions, the underfloor warming heat exchanger contains high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Thermosyphon Vessel

The purpose of the thermosyphon vessel is to provide a supply of liquid ammonia necessary to cool the oil in the compressors. The thermosyphon vessel receives high pressure liquid from the condensers and supplies high pressure liquid to the thermosyphon oil cooler on each screw compressor. Excess liquid in the thermosyphon vessel is piped to the  high pressure receiver. High pressure ammonia vapor formed in each oil cooler is returned to the thermosyphon vessel. Under normal conditions, the thermosyphon vessel contains high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Oil Coolers

The purpose of the oil coolers is to remove heat from the oil being circulated through them. The oil coolers receive liquid from the thermosyphon vessel. High pressure liquid and vapor exits the oil coolers and is returned to the thermosyphon vessel. Under normal conditions, the oil coolers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Auto-Purgers

The purpose of the auto-purgers is to remove non-condensable gases from the systems without requiring the systems to be manually opened. The auto-purgers consist of the following components: water bubbler, foul gas line, liquid line, suction line, water line, drain line, and remote purge point solenoid valves. The auto-purgers remove non-condensable gases by refrigerating the foul gas so that the ammonia vapor condenses to liquid and can be returned to the systems. The non-condensable gases are removed from the systems through the water bubbler. Under normal conditions, the auto-purgers contain small quantities of ammonia and water. 



Safety Systems

Ammonia Detection System

There are fifteen (15) ammonia detectors installed throughout the facility:



East System

(1) Hallway Rooms 1-16 

(1) East Machinery Room



West System

(1) West Machinery Room

(1) Receiving Dock

(1) Loading Dock

(2) Zone A Convertib

le Freezer Room

(1) Zone B Freezer Room

(6) Blast Freezer Corridor

(1) Deslatting Room



The ammonia detectors activate audible and visual alarms at a concentration of 25 ppm. Additionally, a vent line sensor is installed in the West System main relief header which activates an alarm at 35 ppm.



Emergency Control Boxes

The East System Emergency Control Box (ECB) is not contained within a metal box but performs the same function as a typical ECB. The ECB contains four (4) valves:

Valve #1 (Left): High Side Discharge Valve

Valve #2 (Middle): Low Side Discharge Valve

Valve #3 (Right): Low Side Discharge Valve

Valve #4: Water Supply to the Mixing Tank

Opening Valve #4 will allow water into the mixing tank where it can adsorb ammonia released by opening Valves #1-3. Opening Valve #1 will evacuate the process through the high pressure side of the system. Opening Valves #2 and #3 will evacuate the process through the low pressure sides of the system.

The West System Emergency Control Box (ECB) is installed on the east wall of the machinery room and contains nine (9) valves.

Valve #1: Discharge Valve to Diffusion Tank

Valve #2: High Side Discharge Valve

Valve #3: Low Side Discharge Valve (High Temperature Recirculator)

Valve #4: Low Side Discharge Valve (Intermediate Temperature Recirculator)

Valve #5: Low Side Discharge Valve (Low Temperature Recirculator)

Valves #6-9: Higher to Lower Pressure Control Valves

Opening Valves #1 and #2 will evacuate the process through the high pressure side of the system. Opening Valves #1 and #3-5 will evacuate the process through the low pressure sides of the system. Opening Valves #6 and #7-9 will equalize the high and low pressure portions of the system. 



Relief Valves

All ASME pressure vessels and positive displacement compressors are equipped with relief valves designed to relieve pressure and protect the equipment from rupturing. Details regarding the relief valves are summarized below:

Each relief valve has a

set pressure equal to or less than the MAWP of the equipment that the relief valve protects;

All relief valves in the west system are connected to a common manifold which terminates into the ammonia diffusion tank; 

Most relief valves in the east system are connected to a common manifold which terminates to atmosphere, 7.25 ft above the roof;



Diffusion Tank

The West System is equipped with an ammonia diffusion tank which mitigates most of the hazards associated with a relief valve lifting. The relief valve discharge piping is terminated at the bottom of the ammonia diffusion tank. The ammonia diffusion tank is 13.3' dia. x 30' high (31,316.5 gallon capacity). At a water level of 21'-0", the tank contains 21,921.5 gallons of water which exceeds the quantity recommended by ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Addendum A ?15.5.3 which is based on 1 gallon of water per pound of ammonia released through the largest relief valve in the system in 60 minutes. Under normal conditions, the ammonia diffusion tank contains water.



Screw Compressor Safety Devices

Each screw compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each screw compressor package:

High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout, will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.

Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or deviates below the setpoint.

High Oil Temperature Cutout - The high oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Low Oil Temperature Cutout - The low oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or falls below the setpoint

.

Discharge Temperature Cutout - The high discharge temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the discharge temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.



Reciprocating Compressor Safety Devices

Each reciprocating compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each compressor package:

High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout, will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.

Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.

High Level Float Switch



The recirculators, suction accumulator, and intercooler are each equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high liquid level in the vessel. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors.

Main Liquid Feed Shut-Off Valve (King Valve)

The west system high pressure receiver, east system CPR and high pressure receiver 2 are each equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the systems.

Emergency Refrigeration Switch (E-Stop)



The principal entrances to the machinery rooms and the west electrical room are equipped with an emergency refrigeration switch (e-stop) that controls power to the refrigeration machinery inside the machinery rooms. The switches can be activated in an emergency using the hammer next to the switch to break the switch glass.



1.2.4 Process Classification



Each ammonia refrigeration system at Final Mile Cold Storage consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. The systems are neither in

terconnected nor co-located relative to each other. As such, the refrigeration systems at Final Mile Cold Storage are treated as two (2) independent processes.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meetings we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

Final Mile Cold Storage has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration processes. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration processes at the Final Mile Cold Storage facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. The ammonia processes contain a total charge of approximately 54,000 LBS. It is extremely important that each process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration processes and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the processes are checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Final Mile Cold Storage has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Final Mile Cold Storage's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- Cal/OS

HA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements] - Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Final Mile Cold Storage has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Final Mile Cold Storage continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Final Mile Cold Storage's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Final Mile Cold Storage's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Final Mile Cold Storage has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requireme

nt is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Final Mile Cold Storage has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Final Mile Cold Storage now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Final Mile Cold Storage employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Final Mile Cold Storage will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
